Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--The Role of El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) Nonlinearities and Asymmetries in Modulating Tropical Pacific Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project generally aims to develop a multi-scale model-proxy synthesis to explore the relationship between multi-decadal ENSO variability and tropical Pacific seas surface temperature (SST) gradients in past climates and help assess model skill in simulating these relationships in past, present, and potential future climates.

The activity of El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) varies significantly at multi-decadal to centennial timescales, even in the absence of external forcing. Periods of increased ENSO activity may affect the mean state of the tropical Pacific, via a decrease of the zonal SST gradient due to residual heating from large El Niño events. In turn, ENSO-modulated multi-decadal variations of the zonal SST gradient can exert influence on global temperature trends. These causal links are argued to be poorly constrained in models and observations, at present.

The merit of the project is high because it identifies an interesting scientific issue (i.e., the ENSO-mean state interaction) that is important for advancing our understanding the dynamics of ENSO and decadal climate variability that can benefit from using paleo-climate proxies. The anticipated results have the potential to aid in interpreting the decadal variability observed in the present-day climate and the selection of climate models that have the potential to make more accurate projections of future climate.

The Broader Impacts involve the potential for creating increased confidence in theory and models of future climate in the tropics; helping create a new generation of earth scientists willing to bridge the divide between the worlds of modeling and paleoclimate data; support two early career female scientists; and support two doctoral students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Patterns and processes of tropical Pacific climate variability exert a tremendous influence on global climate and global temperature trends. However, the reason for lower-frequency variations in tropical Pacific climate is uncertain, adding an element of uncertainty to future climate projections, especially on decadal to multidecadal timescales. This research assessed the relationship between multidecadal El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) variability and the zonal tropical Pacific sea surface temperature gradient (dSST) in past climates and model skill in simulating this relationship. A comprehensive assessment of annually-resolved paleoclimate reconstructions of ENSO, alongside multidecadal resolution SST reconstructions from the eastern and western tropical Pacific over the last 1000 years highlights the need for more paleoclimate data, but also shows a more frequent negative correlation between ENSO and dSST on multidecadal timescales. Another critical finding is that the direction and strength of the ENSO-dSST relationship varies on multidecadal timescales. A subsequent paleoclimate data comparison with last millennium climate model simulations shows similar variability in the strength and direction of the ENSO-dSST relationship, but models that best simulated modern tropical Pacific climate and ENSO more often exhibited multidecadal periods of a negative-dSST relationship. The alternating directional relationship uncovered in this research has implications for interpretation of low-resolution, low-pass filtered paleoclimate data from the tropical Pacific, and suggests multiple mechanisms link interannual and mean state climate behavior across the tropical Pacific.

 

This work integrated education with the research topic through the development of a graduate course, ‘Paleoclimate Proxy-Model Synthesis.’ The PIs developed and co-taught this course to geology students at the University of Illinois and atmospheric science students at the University of Hawaii. The structure and course materials were devised in an active-learning framework.  In weekly in-class exercises, the students analyzed paleoclimate data and climate model output and experimented with running their own climate model simulations. The capstone project was a paleoclimate data-model comparison of mid-Holocene ENSO teleconnections. Ultimately, the broader impacts of this work highlight the critical role of coupling paleoclimate observations with simulations of past climate in the effort to produce robust estimates of past climate change and improve simulations of future climate.
